text:
Q: python showing following error "unindent does not match any outer indentation level " A:

This error is mostly observed when there is a mixup of Tab and Space characters while indenting Python code. You can use either tab or spaces to indent a code block. Don't use both at a same time.
Your code needs to be like this

while True:
    if (color == guess.lower()):
        break
    else:
        guess = input ("Nope. Try again :")

    #some more

Q: "Podman machine start" : All pipe instances are busy A:

Update WSL

wsl --update

And recreate podman machine (all resources like containers, images, etc will be lost)

podman machine rm
podman machine init
podman machine start

It resolved for me.

Q: moving from C, how to implement doubly linked list in C++ using the c++ features? A:

Hmm. C++ has a lot of features so take it slow, make just some class implementing your list first and work your way through advice from here. The std::list is both a target to compare with and to actually use in practice - as long as you're not in a situation where STL containers aren't enough, stick to STL containers.

Ownership/lifetime is an important but tricky topic. Immediately when I look at your example, I read it as "each struct Node refers to two other nodes with lifetimes unrelated to it, the class refers to two nodes head and tail also with unrelated lifetimes", while if you used std::unique_ptr for them, it'd mean "head and tail live within the class, which contains logic for when they're constructed and destroyed". With smart pointers, implementation is descriptive this way. Think about what ownership model is suitable for you. You can start off with malloc and free and eventually rewrite your code to use smart pointers.

Pretend shared pointers don't exist for now.

Q: how do i get specific values from specific keys in dictionary? A:

.startswith('7') but always gives me an error

What's the error? That sounds like a fine approach to me. The problem might not be where you think it is.

That said, it's a bit odd to have to iterate through a dictionary. How did you find yourself in this situation in the first place? I'm especially confused why the data is duplicated between the dict and the list of dicts.

Q: GitLab Running - Unable to trust self signed certificate A:

CI_SERVER_TLS_CA_FILE is actually a workaround by gitlab (self signed certificate for gitlab.com), you can remove it, because your internal machine (docker container) CA can handle gitlab.com without workarounds.

http.https://gitlab.com.sslcainfo=/home/gitlab-runner/builds/EBo-xXLj/0/user/project.tmp/CI_SERVER_TLS_CA_FILE

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -e

# It will remove CI_SERVER_TLS_CA_FILE.
git config --unset http.https://gitlab.com.sslCAInfo || :

# I can fetch something
git fetch

# I can commit and push something
git add . && git commit -m "update" && git push

Q: Transfer files from one server to another using batch script A:

I recommend you to use the "Add a network location" in the main computer, so you can see a new drive letter with the network location. For your try, it might be wrong the share name on the remote computer, if you share a folder, usually is called by: 

\\IP_or_name_of_the_remote_server\shared_name
